subject: RE: [junit] Testing constructors

messageBody:
Agreed. Large bodies of code (especially in constructors) are generally
a hint that some SERIOUS refactoring is called for. I expect that the
constructor in question contains attributes that could be refactored
into independent objects, each taking care of it's own internal state
validity.

Simon

>-----Original Message-----
>From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jacaetev@...]
>Sent: Friday, January 25, 2002 8:00 AM
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: RE: [junit] Testing constructors
>
>
>Which generally means ripping the privates out into their own
>objects, if
>possible and where appropriate... By the way, keeping the
>internal state of
>the object valid at all times is most preferred. If it gets
>into an invalid
>state, the object ought to throw the appropriate exception and
>be garbage
>collected, or recover itself if possible. Allowing objects to
>float around the
>system with invalid states is a recipe for disaster.
>
>-jason
>
>--- "Chappell, Simon P" <simon.chappell@...> wrote:
>> The only caveat to this advice is to be certain that you keep the
>> internal state of the object valid at all times.
>>
>> Do you have a lot of code in your constructor because of complex
>> internal relationships between the attributes?
>>
>> If you can move code out of your constructor without risking internal
>> validity, then I would certainly recommend it.
>>
>> Simon
>>
>> -----------------------------------------------------------------
>> Simon P. Chappell simon.chappell@...
>> Java Programming Specialist www.landsend.com
>> Lands' End, Inc. (608) 935-4526
>>
>>
>> >-----Original Message-----
>> >From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jacaetev@...]
>> >Sent: Friday, January 25, 2002 7:06 AM
>> >To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>> >Subject: Re: [junit] Testing constructors
>> >
>> >
>> >IMHO, constructors ought to just construct an object to a sane
>> >state, anything
>> >else should be external to the constructor. So, initially I
>> >would take a lot
>> >of the 'functionality' and computation out of the constructor
>> >if possible.
>> >Once the object is constructed, you should be able to test its
>> >state. If not,
>> >there's a code smell there. So, I would suggest that you take
>> >what you can out
>> >of the ctor, construct the object to its known/sane state,
>> >then test against
>> >that.
>> >
>> >HTH.
>> >-jason
>> >--- Thomas Saxtoft <ts@...> wrote:
>> >> Hi
>> >>
>> >> I have some really heavy constructors in some classes. What
>> >is the best
>> >> way to test constructors in generel?
>> >>
>> >> Thomas Saxtoft
